unnormalised: Planning your next trip to Goa and confused about where to book your stay? Don't sweat it! This lil' guide will help you decipher those confusing hotel addresses. I’ve been there, done that, booked the wrong place thanks to vague address listings. Let's prevent that mishap for you!
normalised: Planning your next trip to Goa and confused about where to book your stay? Don't sweat it! This little guide will help you decipher those confusing hotel addresses. I've been there, done that, booked the wrong place thanks to vague address listings. Let's prevent that mishap for you!

unnormalised: First things first, pay attention to the street number. For example, "House No. 123" might seem simple, but in India, street numbering can be...creative. Sometimes numbers skip or repeat. Then there's the "Near XYZ landmark" which can be subjective. What's "near" to the hotel might be a 20-minute auto-rickshaw ride in reality. Look out for localities like "Calangute," "Baga," and "Anjuna." These are popular, but huge. So, "Calangute, Goa" isn't enough.

Sometimes numbers skip or repeat. Then there's the "Near X-Y-Z landmark" which can be subjective. What's "near" to the hotel might be a twenty minute auto-rickshaw ride in reality. Look out for localities like "Calangute," "Baga," and "Anjuna." These are popular, but huge. So, "Calangute, Goa" isn't enough.

unnormalised: Next up: postal codes. Goa's postal codes, like 403516 for example, are crucial. Don't assume all of North Goa has the same pincode! Verify this against the hotel's website or Google Maps. Booking sites sometimes show incorrect info. If booking through OYO, MakeMyTrip, or GoIbibo, double-check the full address on the hotel's official website if possible.

unnormalised: Then comes the "Wards". Many addresses in Goa include a ward number or name, like "Ward 5" or "Vaddo" (a local term). This helps pinpoint the exact area within the village or town. Ignoring this means the auto-rickshaw guy will charge you double just for "searching". He'll probably say “Oh madam, this Goa, address all same same”. Don’t fall for it!

unnormalised: Hotel names, obviously, are important. But don’t JUST rely on them. Lots of hotels share similar names. For example, there might be three "Sunrise Hotels" in North Goa alone! Use the full address with the postal code in Google Maps before booking. It’s a simple step that can save you a lot of trouble.

unnormalised: Finally, once you've booked, note down the entire address EXACTLY as it's given. Include the house number, street name, ward, village/town, postal code, and a nearby landmark. Show it to your auto-rickshaw driver or taxi wallah. And don't be afraid to call the hotel from the airport (or even before you land) to confirm the location, especially if the address seems vague. Happy travels!
